awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Framework: Software: NSCI : Computational and Data Innovation Implementing a National Community Hydrologic Modeling Framework for Scientific Discovery
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the design and implementation of a software framework to simulate the movement of water at various scales. Understanding the movement and availability of water locally and across the country is of paramount importance to economic productivity and human health of our nation. Hydrologic scientists, are actively tackling these challenges using increasingly complex computational methods. However, modeling advances have not been easily translated to the broader community of scientists and professionals due to technical barriers to entry. This software platform draws from computer models and employs supercomputers capable of analyzing big data to provide unprecedented simulations of water movement over the continental US. Combining hydrologists and computer scientists the team behind the project envision a broad community of users who will have multiple ways to interact with the software framework. For the hydrologic scientist who is interested in generating their own scenarios the framework will facilitate direct interaction with the hydrologic models and the ability to generate simulations on the fly. Conversely, the framework will also provide a set of static output and a range of tools for a broader set of users who would like to evaluate hydrologic projections locally or extract model data for use in other analyses.

Continental scale simulation of water flow through rivers, streams and groundwater is an identified grand challenge in hydrology. Decades of model development, combined with advances in solver technology and software engineering have enabled large-scale, high-resolution simulations of the hydrologic cycle over the US, yet substantial technical and communication challenges remain. With support from this award, an interdisciplinary team of computer scientists and hydrologists is developing a framework to leverage advances in computer science transforming simulation and data-driven discovery in the Hydrologic Sciences and beyond. This project is advancing the science behind these national scale hydrologic models, accelerating their capabilities and building novel interfaces for user interaction. The framework brings computational and domain science (hydrology) communities together to move more quickly from tools (models, big data, high-performance computing) to discoveries. It facilitates decadal, national scale simulations, which are an unprecedented resource for both the hydrologic community and the much broader community of people working in water dependent systems (e.g., biological system, energy and food production). These simulations will enable the community to address scientific questions about water availability and dynamics from the watershed to the national scale. Additionally, this framework is designed to facilitate multiple modes of interaction and engage a broad spectrum of users outside the hydrologic community. We will provide easy-to-access pre-processed datasets that can be visualized and plotted using built-in tools that will require no computer science or hydrology background. Recognizing that most hydrology training does not generally include High Performance Computing and data analytics or software engineering, this framework will provide a gateway for computationally enhanced hydrologic discovery. Additionally, for educators we will develop packaged videos and educational modules on different hydrologic systems geared towards K-12 classrooms.

This award by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly supported by the Cross-Cutting Activities Program of the Division of Earth Sciences within the NSF Directorate for Geosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
HydroFrame  project  aims  to  provide  access  to  computational hydrology tools to a large community. Hydrological workflows are complex and involve data pre-processing, model configuration, data analysis and  data  post-processing. Two major requirements of Hydroframe with respect workflow are: (i) to automate of the end-to-end process of hydrologic simulation from selecting regions on map to shape generation, run subsetter, running parflow simulations. And variations of this workflow; (ii) to collect provenance of the entire process for authenticity and reproducibility. Reproducing  workflows  requires  that  users  have  information  one  each  stage  of the workflow about input files, software, configuration, and hardware.


A national scale modeling framework impacts the two principal disciplines of this project (Hydrology and Computer Science) in meaningful ways. The tools used to rapidly prototype national scale hydrologic models are not only immediately useful to hydrologic modelers, but the building blocks of these tools and the back-end infrastructure applies to many other computer science / software engineering endeavors. The workflows developed by UC San Diego enables integration of hydrologic workflows in many settings for different audiences from scientists looking to improve the monitoring and reproducibility of their work to decision-makers and educators interested in hydrologic simulations.


UC San Diego achieved the following outcomes towards the above-mentional intellectual merit and broader impacts of the project:

 

Integrated Provenance DB and Provenance Provider API: ?  We achieved our goal to build Integrated Provenance and Python based Provenance APIs for Hydrological Workflows.

o   Integrated DB ? MongoDB as centralized DB to save provenance from multiple users and executions. The data collected for a specific execution include Workflow Provenance, Workflow high-level performance data - black box, hydrology simulation specific metadata (PFmetadata), Application Performance data - white box - ( eg. timing.csv in parflow).

o   Provenance_Provider Python API ?  Developed python-based Provenance_Provider API. It provides interface to query provenance of Kepler workflow executions. Some examples:

-  load_wfprov_to_intdb - Query the Kepler provenance and load the provenance data to MongoDB.

-  List all the workflows with runids that specific user ran.

-  Get the metadata (parameters, wf xml, time) of a workflow execution using its runid.

-  Update designated fields of metadata of a workflow execution, for example run name, using its uniqueId

-  List all the workflows (by name) saved.

- List all the workflow executions by a user at a specific time.

 

Kepler HPC Workflow for Hydroframe CI: ? This involved designing workflows within constraints of Hydroframe architecture, authentication, interaction with different subsystems, for example, Geomap server, Subsetter, HydroShare, Performance, Verde High Performance Cluster, front-end VM Verde apps,  and others. As the Hydroframe hardware and architecture itself is changing and evolving, it required multiple iterations in building workflow tasks for end-to-end process automation and reproducibility. We built and upgrade (i) Subsetter Workflow ? The workflow generate shape file from HUC_id, creates subset of the inputs from CONUS1 domain (ii) Bulk Clipper Workflow ? The workflow creates mask file, and run Bulk clipper from reference dataset for HUC_ids selected by user from Continental US geo map (iii) Performance Workflow- The wf parses Parflow metadata and exports the performance metrics to MongoDB on VM outside HPCluster. (iv) Kepler PFCLM SC Workflow ? The wf creates subset of inputs from CONUS1 domain, performs hydrological simulations for selected HUC_ids using Parflow simulation on Princeton High Performance Cluster. The Kepler workflow also includes visualization step and additional actors for extensibility and modularity/ reusability.

 

Data Provenance using Blockchain Technology for Input files:?  Worked in collaboration with Boise State University Cathie Olschanowsky?s Group on Data Provenance using Blockchain technology to ensure input files integrity.  Our contribution architecture planning to support blockchain in Kepler workflows for Hydroframe and mentor student in Master?s research thesis with following research objectives are:

i    Build blockchain ledgers for use of scientific workflows.

ii  Implement the new ledger within the Kepler workflow tool.

iii Demonstrate scientific reproducibility using HydroFrame as a case study.


Integrated Kepler Workflows and ProvenanceDB APIs in HydroFrame Flask App

 

The main publication for this project was presented at the ICCS 2020: Purawat S., Olschanowsky C., Condon L.E., Maxwell R., Altintas I. (2020) Scalable Workflow-Driven Hydrologic Analysis in HydroFrame. In: Krzhizhanovskaya V. et al. (eds) Computational Science ? ICCS 2020. ICCS 2020. Lecture Notes in Computer Science, vol 12137. Springer, Cham. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-50371-0_20


Last Modified: 02/17/2023
Modified by: Ilkay Altintas
